arm_group.description: keratoconus with a central corneal thickness (CCT) over 400µm, poor corrected visual acuity (≤0.4 at Snellen visual acuity charts), contact lens intolerance, no apical scarring, no ocular or systemic problem other than keratoconus

brief_summary.textblock:
Keratoconus is a progressive ectatic disorder that steepens the cornea resulting in a
      conical shape. Radial Keratotomy can provide an optical rehabilitation by its flattening
      effect. It can also halt the progression of disease owing to fibrotic activation in
      perpendicular corneal incisions.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy of Radial Keratotomy in the Optical Rehabilitation of Mild to Moderate Keratoconus Cases

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  keratoconus with a central corneal thickness (CCT) over 400µm,

          -  poor corrected visual acuity (≤0.4 at Snellen visual acuity charts),

          -  contact lens intolerance

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  apical scarring,

          -  ocular or systemic problem other than keratoconus

clinical_study.official_title: Efficacy of Radial Keratotomy in the Optical Rehabilitation of Mild to Moderate Keratoconus Cases

oversight_info.authority: Ministry of health, Turkish Republic: Turkey

primary_outcome.description: Preoperative and postoperative uncorrected visual acuity, best spectacle corrected visual acuity, and keratometer readings will be reviewed retrospectively. As reviewed follow up time range is 12 to 52 months, time frame is assessed as " 12 to 52 months"
primary_outcome.measure: outcome measures: uncorrected and best spectacle corrected visual acuity, keratometer readings

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

results_reference.citation: Utine CA, Bayraktar S, Kaya V, Kucuksumer Y, Eren H, Perente I, Yilmaz OF. Radial keratotomy for the optical rehabilitation of mild to moderate keratoconus: more than 5 years' experience. Eur J Ophthalmol. 2006 May-Jun;16(3):376-84.

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case-Only, Time Perspective: Retrospective
